data.subject: GER
data.title: Zeitgeist and Popular Culture
data.description: An introduction to life, society, and culture in modern Germany, Austria, and Switzerland.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Elementary German I
data.description: This course aims to bring German language, culture, and everyday life into the classroom. Students with little or no prior knowledge are introduced to the structure of German and develop their listening/comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Classes are communicative and emphasize interaction in German. Online exercises and audio/video materials accompany each chapter of the textbook.
data.notes: [Note: GER 101 is not open to students with native, near-native or similar advanced ability.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Elementary German II
data.description: A continuation of GER 101.
data.notes: [Note: GER 102 is not open to students with native, near-native or similar advanced ability.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: German and Russian Literary Masterpieces
data.description: An examination of major Russian and German literary works that have influenced world literature.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Intermediate German I
data.description: This course continues the work of GER 101/102. It offers practice in speaking, reading, and writing, with vocabulary building, grammar, and exercises in comprehension.
data.notes: [Note: Students intending to major in German or preparing for work or study terms in German-speaking Europe are encouraged to take GER 201 and 211 concurrently. GER 201 is not open to students with native, near-native or similar advanced ability.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Intermediate German II
data.description: Strengthening of communicative skills, grammar review, vocabulary building, written practice, conversation on issues of contemporary life in German-speaking countries.
data.notes: [Note: Students intending to major in German or preparing for work or study terms in German-speaking Europe are encouraged to take GER 202 and 212 concurrently. GER 202 is not open to students with native, near-native or similar advanced ability.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Integrative Language Seminar I
data.description: This course develops reading, writing, and oral skills, and intercultural competence.
data.notes: [Note: Students may take GER 201 and 211 concurrently.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Integrative Language Seminar II
data.description: This course builds on GER 211 to develop competence in reading, writing, oral skills, and intercultural competence.
data.notes: [Note: Students may take GER 202 and 212 concurrently. Formerly GER 204.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Once Upon a Fairy Tale: Fairy Tales, Then and Now
data.description: This course studies fairy tales in the broader context of the history of childhood and practices of education and socialization. The course will concentrate on the German and Russian context and in particular on the work of the Brothers Grimm and Alexander Afanasyev, and will also consider fairy tales drawn from a number of different national traditions and historical periods.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Performance German I
data.description: This course improves students' oral and written skills via creative performances in our everyday life. Students will be actively involved in marketing products, conducting job interviews, writing CVs, improvising theatre skits, hosting poetry slams, or even instructing yoga - all in German.

data.subject: GER
data.title: German Thought and Culture: Objects
data.description: An exploration of human-made objects that open up perspectives on German-speaking society and culture. Objects to be studied might include the Berlin Wall, the swastika, Luther's Bible, donairs, and Volkswagens. Students acquire skills in cultural analysis and learn about major developments in literature, philosophy, religion, art, architecture, and music.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: German Thought and Culture: People
data.description: An exploration of key figures whose contributions to the arts and intellectual life have shaped German-speaking society and culture. Persons to be studied might include Friedrich Nietzsche, Sigmund Freud, Leni Riefenstahl, and Hannah Arendt. Students acquire skills in cultural analysis and learn about major developments in literature, philosophy, religion, art, architecture, and music.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Cultural Studies
data.description: Selected topics in cultural studies.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: German Abroad
data.description: This immersion course provides students with an introduction to and a familiarity with selected topics in German-speaking environments. The topics range from history and culture, to language and linguistic varieties in the German-speaking world, as well as arts and the German-speaking media landscape. Course offerings include classes abroad as well as field trips.
data.notes: [Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Interactive German Language and Culture
data.description: This course develops German language skills and cultural awareness. Discussions include such topics as Heimat, nation, migration, and study abroad. Students will engage with and reflect on different social and cultural perspectives through interviews, videos, and texts. Online interactions, including with people in and from Germany, form an integral part of the course.
data.notes: [Note: Offered through University of Guelph in alternating years, but always available to both University of Waterloo and University of Guelph students.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Reading and Translating
data.description: Students learn strategies for understanding a variety of texts such as newspaper reports, manuals, and fiction. Translation exercises are used to improve language skills.
data.notes: [Note: Students majoring in German or preparing for work or study terms in German-speaking Europe are encouraged to take GER 304 in tandem with any of GER 307, 308, 331, 334.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: German for Professional Purposes
data.description: This language course teaches students the skills needed to function in German business and professional environments. Praxis-oriented language and intercultural training are combined with a discussion of the German business world.

data.subject: GER
data.title: German through Comics
data.description: German-language comic strips and graphic novels enable students to explore modern language use. Colloquial German language skills are sharpened in this course, and the place of the comic strip and graphic novel in society is discussed.

data.subject: GER
data.title: The Structure of German
data.description: Students in this course investigate grammar phenomena in electronic corpora (large principled collections of texts) to develop their language awareness and the accuracy and appropriateness of their written German.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Exploring the German Language
data.description: An introduction to the study of linguistics with a focus on developing the German language skills necessary for linguistic analysis.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Exploring German Literature
data.description: An introduction to the study of prose, poetry, and theatre. Periods in German literary history, forms of literary expression, and the methodologies used to analyze these forms are examined. Special attention is also paid to developing the German language skills necessary for literary interpretation.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Performance German II
data.description:
This course improves students' more advanced oral and written skills via creative performances in our everyday life. Students will be actively involved in marketing products, conducting job interviews, writing CVs, improvising theatre skits, hosting poetry slams, or even
instructing yoga - all in German.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Intermediate Conversation and Composition on Topics in German "Landeskunde"
data.description: Conversation and composition on topics in German "Landeskunde" with grammar review and study of German vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. This course is taught in Mannheim in conjunction with the '"Waterloo in Germany" program.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Intermediate Conversation and Composition on Topics in German "Landeskunde"
data.description: Conversation and composition on topics in German "Landeskunde" with grammar review and study of German vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. This course is taught in Mannheim in conjunction with the "Waterloo in Germany" program.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Culture in the Third Reich: Racism, Resistance, Legacy
data.description: An examination of German culture during the Nazi period (1933-1945). The course will analyze representations of Nazi ideology in the arts (film, art, architecture, and propaganda), the literature of exile and "inner emigration," and the impact of the Nazi legacy on post-war German culture.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Culture Behind the Iron Curtain
data.description: An examination of the culture of the Soviet Union, the German Democratic Republic, and other states that experimented with socialism in the 20th century. Representations of Marxist-Leninist and Stalinist ideologies in literature, cinema, and the arts; the role of the state in directing cultural expression; and resistance to totalitarian control of culture are examined. Western representations of the Cold War are also studied.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. GER 385 will have a German language component for students in German academic plans. REES 385 will have a Russian language component for students in Russian and East European academic plans.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Waterloo in Germany Program
data.description: Study abroad at a German university in the fall term.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Waterloo in Germany Program
data.description: Study abroad at a German university in the winter term.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Waterloo in Germany Program
data.description: Study abroad at a German university in the spring term.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Cultural Studies
data.description: Selected topics in cultural studies.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: German Abroad
data.description: This immersion course provides students with an introduction to and a familiarity with selected topics in German-speaking environments. The topics range from history and culture, to language and linguistic varieties in the German-speaking world, as well as arts and the German-speaking media landscape. Course offerings include classes abroad as well as field trips.
data.notes: [Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Applied Apprenticeship
data.description: For Honours German students interested in a career in international business. The course involves an apprenticeship in an industrial setting in Germany, Austria or Switzerland of no less than twelve weeks combined with weekly written reports, a presentation, and a final report. The course is offered on a credit/non-credit basis and cannot be used to meet the Core German Course requirement. Due to the costs involved with working in a foreign country, paid positions are eligible for credit in the course.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Language Pedagogy
data.description: Topics in the instruction of German and other foreign/second languages.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times. Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Senior Seminar
data.description: Topics in German literary and cultural studies, and linguistics chosen by the instructor in consultation with the department. These courses reflect research interests of the faculty and form part of a well-rounded undergraduate education in "Germanistik".
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of ten times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Senior Honours Project
data.description: German Honours students in their third or fourth year may complete, with departmental permission, a major project, the results of which must be presented in a substantial essay. The topic should reflect the student's field of interest.
data.notes: [Note: Requests for permission should be submitted to the undergraduate officer, in consultation with the intended faculty advisor, and should include an outline of the project and a bibliography. The project will be assessed and graded by two faculty members.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Reading Course in Approved Topics
data.description: Reading course in topics chosen in consultation with an advisor.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Methods of Research
data.description: A course designed to foster an understanding of the fundamental notions of critical inquiry and to provide training in intellectual and practical skills common to research in the areas of applied linguistics, film and literary studies.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Approaches in Literary and Cultural Theory
data.description: Major currents in twentieth-century literary theory are discussed and applied to primary texts so that students can develop their own critical position.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Approaches in Film and Performance Theory

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Second Language Acquisition and Computer Assisted Language Learning

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in German Literature and Culture

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Comparative Literature and Culture

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Film and Electronic Media

data.title: Topics in Literature and Cultural Theory

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Linguistic Methodology
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Theories and Models of Applied Linguistics
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany

data.title: Topics in Theories and Methods of Cultural and Literary Studies
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in Theories and Conceptions of Modernity
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in Interaction and Text
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in History of Language
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in German Grammar
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in Individual and Society in Historical Transformation
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.title: Topics in Aesthetic Transformations and Theoretical Concepts
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Intercultural Perspectives, Post-colonial Constellations & Transnational Discourses
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in German Literature and Culture Before 1700
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in German Literature and Culture Before 1700
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Modern German Literature
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Media Studies
data.description: This course is taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Master's Thesis Colloquium
data.description: The function of the MA Colloquium is the preparation and discussion of the MA thesis.  It covers key components of the thesis and the writing process, such as theoretical reflection on relevant literary, cultural, linguistic or media theories, research methodologies, existing research and the writing of a research report, as well as techniques for presenting research results.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Academic Writing
data.description: Writing skills do provide an important tool in the academic world and are necessary for writing essays, presentations and research papers.  However well you know your subject, it is not necessarily an easy task to talk and write about it.  Therefore this course is designed for students who want to develop or imporove their academic writing skills and presentation techniques.  The focus of the course is on processes of generating ideas, collecting information, and establishing a thesis statement.  Furthermore it also gives an introduction to the development, structure, argumentation forms, and stylistic issues of academic papers with special attention to North American usage.  This course is taught either in Waterloo or Mannheim Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: German and Russian Literary Masterpieces
data.description: An examination of major Russian and German literary works that have influenced world literature.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Once Upon a Fairy Tale: Fairy Tales, Then and Now
data.description: This course studies fairy tales in the broader context of the history of childhood and practices of education and socialization. The course will concentrate on the German and Russian context and in particular on the work of the Brothers Grimm and Alexander Afanasyev, and will also consider fairy tales drawn from a number of different national traditions and historical periods.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Culture Behind the Iron Curtain
data.description: An examination of the culture of the Soviet Union, the German Democratic Republic, and other states that experimented with socialism in the 20th century. Representations of Marxist-Leninist and Stalinist ideologies in literature, cinema, and the arts; the role of the state in directing cultural expression; and resistance to totalitarian control of culture are examined. Western representations of the Cold War are also studied.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. GER 385 will have a German language component for students in German academic plans. REES 385 will have a Russian language component for students in Russian and East European academic plans.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Language Pedagogy
data.description: Topics in the instruction of German and other foreign/second languages.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times. Taught in English.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Performance German I
data.description: This course improves students' oral and written skills via creative performances in our everyday life. Students will be actively involved in marketing products, conducting job interviews, writing CVs, improvising theatre skits, hosting poetry slams, or even instructing yoga - all in German.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Written Communication
data.description: The most important elements of German grammar are examined, and students develop the skills necessary for various types of written communication.
data.prerequisites: GER 102 or OAC German or 4U German
data.notes: [Note: Students intending to major in German or preparing for work or study terms in German-speaking Europe are encouraged to take GER 201 and 203 concurrently. Students who wish to take only one German language course in a semester are encouraged to start with GER 201 if they feel a need to review basic concepts, and GER 203 if they wish to focus on their written skills. GER 203 is not open to students with native, near-native or similar advanced ability.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Integrative Language Seminar II
data.description: This course builds on GER 211 to develop competence in reading, writing, oral skills, and intercultural competence.
data.notes: [Note: Students may take GER 202 and 212 concurrently. Formerly GER 204.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Survey of German Literature and Culture
data.description: Introduction to the major periods of German literature and culture.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Survey of German Literature and Culture
data.description: A continuation of GER 291.

data.subject: GER
data.title: German for Professional Purposes I
data.description: A third-year language course concentrating on the language requirements for the modern workplace. Praxis-oriented language and inter-cultural training combined with discussion of the German business world, in particular business organization and the marketplace.

data.subject: GER
data.title: German for Professional Purposes II
data.description: A third-year language course concentrating on the language requirements for the modern workplace. Praxis-oriented language and inter-cultural training combined with discussion of the German business world, in particular industrial production and international trade.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Studies in Genre (Prose and Poetry)
data.description: An introduction to the study of prose and poetry with a special focus on developing the German language skills necessary for analysis of these genres.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Studies in Genre (Theatre and Film)
data.description: An introduction to the study of theatre and film with a special focus on developing the German language skills necessary for analysis of these genres.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Topics in Intercultural Perspectives
data.description: This course is normally taught in Mannheim, Germany.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Transcultural Studies
data.description: This course provides an introduction to transcultural views of literature, film, language, and literature and media culture (e.g., fairy tales and their adaptation in other cultures, authors who work in multiple languages, transcultural comics, multilingual and transcultural films, local cultures' interaction with global arts and media scenes, etc.).
data.notes: [Note: Lectures and readings in English. No knowledge of German required.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Vikings!
data.description: This course will examine the Viking Age cultures, which flourished in Northern Europe and beyond from c. 800 to 1100 C.E.. The goal of this course is to familiarize students with the Viking Age and to deepen students' understanding of the processes through which peoples in the present give meaning to the past.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English; no knowledge of other languages required.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Knowledge Transfer & Reflection
data.description: The course encompasses two learning elements: A Knowledge Transfer Project and an Intercultural Reflection. Both elements are designed to encourage reflection on your academic and experiential learning progress and to engage with a wider audience.

data.subject: GER
data.title: Great German Thinkers
data.description: An introduction to and examination of the thought of one important figure (such as Leibniz, Kant, Nietzsche, or Heidegger) or school (such as Idealism, Romanticism, or phenomenology) of German philosophy. The choice of the philosopher(s) studied varies from term to term.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: GER
data.title: Great German Thinkers
data.description: An introduction to and examination of the thought of one important figure (such as Leibniz, Kant, Nietzsche, or Heidegger) or school (such as Idealism, Romanticism, or phenomenology) of German philosophy. The choice of the philosopher(s) studied varies from term to term.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]
